docs.lead_paragraph: If ever there was a perfect person to test for a newly discovered colon cancer gene, it was a 50-year-old Maryland woman named Candace. Colon cancer was in her family: her mother died of it three years ago, at age 82. And a test showed that her brother had inherited the colon cancer gene. That meant Candace might have it, too. Candace, who spoke on condition that she not be identified, lived in fear that she would die of colon cancer and that she had passed on a predisposition to colon cancer to her children. The test would tell her if she had the gene.

headline.main: Genetic Testing Falls Short of Public Embrace

docs.abstract: New tests for breast and colon cancer genes were expected to be gold mine for manufacturers, but those selling tests say number of people being tested is in hundreds, not thousands; many people expected to want tests are turning away; some fear discrimination in insurance or in job market; others are not sure how knowing they have gene would help them; still others simply do not want to know whether they have gene or not (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: PHARMACEUTICAL RESOURCES INC., Spring Valley, N.Y., said Lipha Americas, a unit of the German pharmaceutical company Merck K.G.a.A., would buy 10.4 million newly issued Pharmaceutical Resources shares for $2 a share in cash. PAN-AMERICAN LIFE INSURANCE CO., New Orleans, will quit the United States health insurance market to concentrate on its life insurance and retirement planning businesses. As a result, 300 employees, or 20 percent of the company's 1,500-member work force, will be dismissed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stepping into one of the thorniest issues in medicine, the Clinton Administration today ordered the private network that distributes donated organs to replace its current system with one that gives priority to the sickest patients, no matter where in the country they live. But the architect of the controversial order, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, declined to offer any specifics about what the new system should look like. Dr. Shalala left it up to the network, the nonprofit United Network for Organ Sharing, giving it five months to devise a plan that will even out waiting times for donated organs across the nation.

headline.main: U.S. Orders Sickest to Be Given Priority on Donated Organs

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration orders private network that distributes donated organs to replace its current system with one that gives priority to sickest patients, no matter where in country they live; Donna E Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, leaves it up to network, nonprofit United Network for Organ Sharing, to devise plan that will even out waiting times for donated organs across nation; Shalala's order means end of system in which donated organs remain within narrow geographic boundaries, resulting in waiting times that vary greatly among regions; network intends to fight new regulation, or notion that it must for first time submit to Government oversight (M)
docs.snippet: Stepping into one of the thorniest issues in medicine, the Clinton Administration today ordered the private network that distributes donated organs to replace its current system with one that gives priority to the sickest patients, no matter where in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, the widow of John Hay (Jock) Whitney, the first wife of James Roosevelt and the last of the three glamorous Cushing sisters of Boston, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. She was 89. Mrs. Whitney was one of the most prestigious figures in New York society, although she disliked publicity and rarely attended large social gatherings. When she did appear at an event, it was considered a coup.

headline.main: Betsey Cushing Whitney Is Dead at 89

docs.abstract: Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, widow of John Hay (Jock) Whitney, first wife of James Roosevelt and last of three glamorous Cushing sisters of Boston, dies at age 89; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: He said that his name was Arthur Bell and that he had once been a dancer. Now he could hardly stand. Two paramedics had taken him to Kings County Hospital Center this month after they noticed him on Bedford Street in Brooklyn: an old man who kept falling on the pavement, his balance as undone as his dignity.

headline.main: Through Sad Haze, A Glimpse of Beauty; Homeless Man's Past Emerges: A Black Pioneer in the Ballet

docs.abstract: Social worker Maria Mackin, former balet photographer, discusses plight of homeless man Arthur Bell, former ballet dancer in late 1940's and early 1950's, who currently suffers from memory loss except for recalling his dancing years; historians say that he was first black man to perform with New York City Ballet; questions concerning his medical insurance and eligibility for Medicare discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Barry G. Chaiken started out as an ophthalmologist in Manhattan 15 years ago, he saw patients in managed care plans, though he was not crazy about the idea. He did not last long. After he had to ask three people to authorize a laser procedure for a patient, he quit. He could not abide the idea of his medical judgment being questioned. Now Dr. Chaiken, 46, is joining forces with other doctors who have jumped off the managed care bandwagon. At a time when the vast majority of their colleagues are aboard such plans, that is a tough decision. But they hope to find strength in numbers.

headline.main: A Medical Resistance Movement; As Independence Fades, Doctors Fight Care Plans

docs.abstract: Some doctors in California and New York, alarmed by what they see as harmful interference in the way they practice medicine and resentful of lower fees paid by managed health care companies, are banding together in associations of 'independent' doctors; doctors are staking their livelihoods on gamble that they can convince enough people that old-fashioned medicine is worth the cost; groups plan to serve as loose referral networks, helping patients who plan to pay out of pocket or have traditional insurance to find doctors who tailor their practices to fewer patients and less restrictive care; Dr Barry Chaiken, founder of new Association of Independent Physicians in New York, comments; chart; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A day after a committee overhauling the state's auto insurance laws agreed to let insurers offer low-cost policies with sharply reduced medical coverage, a coalition of health organizations criticized the proposal yesterday as unsound. The committee, which Governor Whitman has asked to submit recommendations by March 31, proposed to allow so-called mini-policies with annual premiums of $350 -- the current average is $1,099 -- and limit medical benefits to $15,000.
docs.abstract: Coalition of health organizations, one day after committee overhauling New Jersey's auto insurance laws agreed to let insurers offer low-cost policies with sharply reduced medical coverage, criticizes proposal as unsound (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For two years and one month, Mindy Ervin has waited in uneasy limbo for a new liver. Too well to be ushered to the top of the transplant list, yet so sick that she has already planned her own funeral, she spends her days in bed, hoping the telephone will ring with news of an available organ. A former nurse who suffers a rare autoimmune disease, Mrs. Ervin, of Portsmouth, R.I., lives in the region with the nation's longest wait for livers. She cannot have her transplant in Florida, where waiting times are shorter; her insurance company will not permit it. Five weeks ago, she endured a devastating false alarm. She dashed to the New England Medical Center in Boston for the long-awaited operation, only to learn that the donated organ was unsuitable.

headline.main: Patients' Lives on the Line In Battle Over Transplants

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration is about to dismantle regional system for distributing donated organs for transplants and replace it with national list in which sickest patients would get priority; Health and Human Services Sec Donna E Shalala says change would even out waiting times and insure that very sick people do not die waiting while those who are less acutely ill receive transplants; Shalala's plan has done little to ease minds of patients and even less to settle debate about how organs--and in particular livers, which are in short supply--should be distributed; it has exposed nasty political and economic fight between large and small transplant centers, each vying for its share of lucrative transplant business, in which operation can cost $250,000; map; photo of Michael and Mindy Ervin of Portsmouth, RI, who are waiting to find out how new transplant policy could affect her chances of receiving liver (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Celebrity's Son: Big Connections and Addictions'' (news article, March 20): You report that William Cope Moyers is lobbying for ''legislation requiring that insurance companies classify addiction as a disease, and pay for the same kind of treatment they allow for other illnesses.'' He is on target. The Americans With Disabilities Act already classifies alcoholism as a disability.
docs.abstract: George O'Donnell and Gerald Miller letter praises William Cope Moyers for lobbying for legislation requiring that insurance companies classify drug addiction as disease

docs.lead_paragraph: A friend of mine recently ran for office on the ticket of a right-of-center political party. He'd call me late at night, after finishing a hard day of campaigning, and burst into a self-mocking parody of the speeches he had been embarrassing himself by making from dawn to dusk. ''Let me say how sickened I am by the evils of child abuse! I yield to no one in my condemnation of the illegal trade in puppies! We must move ahead, while leaving nobody behind!'' My friend is a British Conservative, but he could just as well have been running for Congress as a Republican. The vapid, empty politics he was ridiculing has become almost the official credo of Congressional Republicans. The party's politics today careers wildly from feel-good mini-policies a la Dick Morris (the cigarette tax increase) to vast but empty gestures (the repeal of the Internal Revenue Code).
docs.abstract: David Frum Op-Ed article scores effort of Republicans in Congress to hold onto their majority by refraining from doing anything at all; scores their abandonment of plans to reform operation of Federal Government that swept them to victory four years ago; suggests they press for no net increase in per-person Federal spending; drawing (M)
